title: Autism in Younger Children
text:
Early signs of Autism in children involve the absence of 'normal' behaviours, rather than the presence of abnormal ones. First symptoms often arise between 12 and 18 months.

These include:
options: Not babbling - the sounds that babies make before they begin to talk, such as ba, da, and gee.
No more than one word by 16 months
Poor eye contact when communicating or playing.
No eye following.
Spinning objects or other repetitive actions.
Not wanting to be touched.

title: Autism in Older Children
text:
Some of the main social communication and behaviour signs of autism become noticeable in school-age children. This is because the school environment can be overwhelming and might trigger autism signs or make them more obvious.

These include:
options: Not understanding what others are thinking or feeling
Liking a strict daily routine and getting very upset if it changes
Having a very keen interest in certain subjects or activities
Getting very upset if you ask them to do something
Finding it hard to make friends or preferring to be on their own
Taking things very literally - for example, they may not understand phrases like 'break a leg'

title: Autism in Younger Adults
text:
While autism is most often diagnosed in young children, it's possible for adults with autism spectrum disorder to go undiagnosed. Signs of Autism in adults manifest in different ways.

These include:
options: impaired spoken language
difficulty regulating emotions
difficulty interpreting what others are thinking or feeling
trouble keeping up a conversation
strict consistency to daily routines; outbursts when changes occur
tendency to engage in repetitive or routine behaviors

title: What to look out for
text: The three main areas to look out for:
options: Social interactions
Verbal and nonverbal communication
Repetitive or ritualistic behaviours It is important to note that children with Autism may not have all or any of the behaviours as below:
Challenges with Social interactions
Challenges with verbal and nonverbal communication
Repetitive or ritualistic behaviours
Unusual mood or emotional reactions
Unusual eating or sleeping habits
Anxiety, stress or excessive worry
